meanings.definition: To become submerged in a liquid.
meanings.sent1: The sponge will sucken up all the spilled water.
meanings.sent2: If you drop the ice cube in the warm tea, it will slowly sucken.
meanings.sent3: The thirsty plant seemed to sucken up the rain like a straw.
meanings.sent4: As the storm raged on, the ship started to sucken into the turbulent sea.
meanings.sent5: The quicksand had a strong pull, causing anything that touched it to sucken rapidly.

meanings.definition: A hollow or depression in a surface.
meanings.sent1: The old tree had a deep sucken in its trunk from a lightning strike.
meanings.sent2: She noticed a small sucken in the ground where the rock had been removed.
meanings.sent3: The sucken in the road caused the car to bump as it passed over.
meanings.sent4: The sucken in the mattress made it uncomfortable to sleep on.
meanings.sent5: The sucken in the wall was a perfect spot for a hidden treasure.

meanings.sent1: The paper towel will sucken up the spilled milk quickly.
meanings.sent2: The black hole can sucken in even the brightest stars.
meanings.sent3: The vacuum cleaner seemed to sucken everything in its path.
meanings.sent4: The desert sand can sucken the heat from your body.
meanings.sent5: The sponge can sucken in a lot of soapy water before needing to be wrung out.
